basics.name: Luong Tin Phan
basics.label: Robotics Engineer/Scientist
basics.summary: I am a robotics engineer/scientist with a passion for developing innovative solutions in the field of robotics. I have a strong background in robotics, software development, machine learning. My goal is to contribute to the advancement of robotics technology and its applications in various industries.

work.name: Next Robotics
work.summary: Teaching at Palmer Physical Laboratory (now 302 Frist Campus Center). While not a professor at Princeton, I associated with the physics professors and continued to give lectures on campus.

awards.title: Full Scholarship for PhD Program
awards.summary: Awarded a full scholarship for the PhD program in Robotics at Sungkyunkwan University, covering tuition and living expenses.

latest publications.name: Development of A Quadruped Robot System with Torque-Controllable Modular Actuator Unit
latest publications.summary: It concerned an interpretation of the Michelson–Morley experiment and the properties of light and time. Special relativity incorporates the principle that the speed of light is the same for all inertial observers regardless of the state of motion of the source.

latest publications.name: Study on Effects of Spinal Joint for Running Quadruped Robots
latest publications.summary: In the second paper, he applied the quantum theory to light to explain the photoelectric effect. In particular, he used the idea of light quanta (photons) to explain experimental results, but stressed the importance of the experimental results. The importance of his work on the photoelectric effect earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.

projects.name: Quantum Computing
projects.summary: Quantum computing is the use of quantum-mechanical phenomena such as superposition and entanglement to perform computation. Computers that perform quantum computations are known as quantum computers.
